The king said:
No,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½

The king said:

The king said:
No,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
For this reason I say that your doubts are as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, and the Buddhas cannot explain them.
Why is it so?
Can one defile the sky with dust?
The king said:
No,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
If someone says they can remove the defilements of space,
can they remove them?
The king said:

MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said:

Why is it so?

Therefore I say that even if Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges were to explain it, the king's doubts would not be resolved.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« further said:
The TathÄgata does not grasp at the mind of self and others. What doubts can there be?
Why is it so?
All dharmas are originally liberated.
Why then have doubts?
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« further said:

That which is originally liberated is not attached to emptiness. All dharmas are originally non-existent, therefore they are said to be liberated. They are neither spontaneous nor accomplished, and there is nothing to be seen.
All dharmas, whether existent or non-existent, are seen as non-existent, and therefore nothing can be seen. All dharmas are said to be silent, and therefore conceptualization cannot be known.
All dharmas are without conceptualization, and have already transcended naturalness, and therefore transcend.
All dharmas are said to be the cessation of birth and death.
All dharmas have no location, because there are no wishes.
All dharmas have no wishes, because there is no birth and death.
All dharmas are without attachment, because they are pure.
All dharmas are completely pure, because internally and externally they are all pure.
All dharmas have no counterpart, because they have no companions.
All dharmas have no companions, because they are one-pointed.
All dharmas are one-pointed, because they are liberated.ğŸ”½All dharmas have no extreme, because there is nothing to be cut off.
All dharmas have no boundaries, because there is no limit.
All dharmas cannot be seen to have a limit, because what is done is different.
The so-called various dharmas are those whose activities are different. Seeking wisdom is called being unable to attain peace.
All dharmas are impermanent, because there is no second mind.
All dharmas are peaceful, because they transcend purity.
All dharmas are decisive, because there is nothing to seek.
There are no naturally occurring dharmas, because the body cannot be attained.
All dharmas are free from doubt, because they are internally tranquil.
How marvelous are all dharmas, because they are devoid of truth.
All dharmas are tranquil, because they are level and even.
All dharmas are without self, because they are not one's own.
All dharmas are without remainder, because they are liberated.ğŸ”½All dharmas are without turning, because they are without thought.
All dharmas are fully trusted, because they are severed without attachment.
All dharmas are of one taste, because they are liberated.ğŸ”½All dharmas are peaceful, because they are without conceptualization.
All dharmas are without conceptualization, because they are indestructible.
All dharmas are empty, because they transcend all seeking.
All dharmas are without aspiration, because they are the three realms.
All dharmas are severed from the three realms, because they are not attached to the past, future, or present.
All dharmas are nirvÄá¹‡a, because what is born has not yet been born.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said to AjÄtaÅ›atru:
Non-arising.
Only that which is non-arising can be made pure.
The king said:
No,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said:
The Buddha knows that all dharmas are like nirvÄá¹‡a, and therefore cannot be freed from their doubts.

One should directly abide and observe all dharmas.

Having observed all dharmas, there is nothing to grasp or abandon, and one does not dwell in any dharmas. Since one has already dwelled in no dharmas, one is thus at ease. Having attained ease, one then has no doubts. Having no doubts, one then has no activity. Having no activity means having no master. One should have acceptance within this.
Why is it so?
Do not think that you use the dharmas, and therefore endure the dharmas as unworkable, saying they can be or cannot be.
The dharmas have no work, no work and nothing to work on, therefore they are nirvana.
Those who have faith in this are considered equally liberated, with nothing to add and nothing to subtract.

Because the dharmas are originally non-existent, there is no work. That which can work is all originally non-existent. That which is originally non-existent is neither this nor not this, therefore originally non-existent is without difference.
Having already believed in the absence of difference, all doubts have been exhausted.
The eyes are neither defiled nor pure. The eyes are as they naturally are, therefore originally non-existent. Originally non-existent and as they naturally are, therefore called eyes.

The ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind are also neither defiled nor pure. The mind is as it naturally is, therefore originally non-existent. Originally non-existent and as it naturally is, therefore called mind.
Form is also originally non-existent, originally non-existent and as form naturally is.

Pain, thought, life and death, and consciousness are also without defilement and also without purity. Consciousness is naturally originally non-existent, and because of the original non-existence of nature, it is called consciousness.
All dharmas are without defilement and without purity. Dharmas are naturally originally non-existent, and because of the original non-existence of nature, they are called dharmas.
The mind is also invisible, and form cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
It is like an illusion, which cannot be said to be used internally, nor can it be said to be used externally.
Why is it so?

The original mind is neither received, nor increased, nor troubled, nor worried, nor sorrowful.

Those who hear this Dharma have no doubts. Because the original is different and the thought is different, there is defilement. One should know that the original is different and the thought is different. Those who do not have this cannot be made to have it.
The king should not think of having this.
It is like a person saying they can make the sky dirty with smoke or dust, can they make the sky dirty in this way?
The king said:
No,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½

It is like a person saying what they do is either done by themselves or not done by themselves, then there is desire, anger, and delusion.
In the original mind, it does not make dirt nor does it make doubt.
Why is it so?ğŸ”½Because the originally created mind cannot prevent the later mind;
the later created mind does not seek the previous mind;
the present mind also has no place.
The wise ones understand this activity, yet they have no expectations. Because there are no expectations, it is the characteristic of purity.
All dharmas are without defilement, without ignorance, without arising, and without location.
Without location is the birthplace of the Buddha. The birthplace refers to the dharmas. The dharmas are therefore the birthplace, and thus cannot be spoken of.

The wise ones, the dharmas are without liberation. Using the Dharma to liberate from doubts, using non-existence to liberate from the Dharma, therefore doubts belong to the Dharma body. Thus, it is said that the Dharma body enters all dharmas, yet also does not see the Dharma body entering anywhere.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are the Dharma body.
Because the dharmas are equal, the Dharma body is also equal. Therefore, it is said that the Dharma body enters.
When this was said, King Ajatashatru attained the acceptance of joy and faith, and then joyfully exclaimed:
Excellent, excellent!
To resolve my doubts.

This is a great doubt.
The Dharma that was spoken of earlier has no basis, so how can there be doubt?
From where should one hear doubt?

Now, for me whose life is ending, I am not worried about not reaching nirvana.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said:
As the king's aspirations, they have no basis.

King AjÄtaÅ›atru then rose from his seat, took a precious robe worth hundreds of thousands, held it and circled around MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«'s body.
At that moment, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«'s body disappeared, and the robe remained in the sky. Only his voice was heard, but his form was not seen, and then the sound was heard, saying:
As you see MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«'s body, you yourself have doubts.
Not seeing through doubt, as you see, is it seeing all dharmas as they are?
Again, a voice was heard from the sky, saying:
If the king sees anything, he should give it to them with a cloth.
Next, in the seat of MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, there was a bodhisattva named Attaining the Supreme Vow.
AjÄtaÅ›atru again wanted to offer the cloth to him.
That bodhisattva said:
I do not accept anything from those who seek liberation and nirvÄá¹‡a, nor do I accept anything from ordinary people.

I also do not accept anything from those who seek to become arhats or pratyekabuddhas, nor do I accept anything from the teachings of the TathÄgatas. I accept this object from those who do not approach this Dharma or depart from this Dharma.
The giver also has no dualistic mind, and the receiver also has no dualistic mind. Therefore, it is said that what is received surpasses liberation.
The king then wanted to put the robe on the bodhisattva, but suddenly he disappeared and no one knew where he was. He only heard his voice but did not see his form, saying:
Give the robe to the one whose body is manifested.
This bodhisattva was sitting next to another bodhisattva named Jianzhuhuan (Seeing All Illusions).
King Ajatashatru again offered the robe to him.
That bodhisattva said:
If there are those who conceive of others as having a self, I do not accept this object. I also do not accept it from those who are defiled, nor do I accept it from those who seek liberation.
I do not accept this object from those who are in samÄdhi, nor do I accept it from those whose minds are in chaos.
I do not accept this object from those who have wisdom, nor do I accept it from those who lack wisdom.
Ajatashatru then threw the robe onto the bed, and the bodhisattva immediately disappeared. He again heard the voice but did not see the form, saying:
Give the robe to whoever appears.
But in the seat where the bodhisattva was sitting, there was a bodhisattva named Adarashanirvanagamin.
Ajatashatru held the robe in his hands and went to him, saying:
The senior monk has left, you may accept it.
That bodhisattva said:
If there is anyone who clings to others, I do not accept this thing.
One who does not cling to the five aggregates, the four elements, or the six sense objects, does not cling to the Buddha, the Dharma, or the Sangha.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas are without attachment.
King Ajatashatru then held the robe and wanted to put it on the bodhisattva, but the bodhisattva immediately disappeared. He only heard the voice but did not see the form, saying:
There was a bodhisattva named Shihemo sitting next to him.
Ajatashatru then offered him his robe.
The bodhisattva said:
I do not accept offerings from those who have no regard for others.

Now, if you give rise to the bodhisattva mind, uphold the mind like a bodhisattva, if your mind is equal to all dharmas, and also equal to the buddhas' teachings, if you do not grasp or abandon anything, if you have no doubts about any dharmas and also no doubts, if you do not think that any dharmas have a self, and do not think that any dharmas are liberated, if you have this intention, then I will accept these offerings.
King Ajatashatru then placed the robe on the bodhisattva, but the bodhisattva immediately disappeared and could only be heard saying:
Give the robe to whoever appears.
There was a bodhisattva named Sanmei Jushoumo sitting next to him.

The bodhisattva said:

King AjÄtaÅ›atru then held the robe and placed it on him, but he immediately disappeared and only heard his voice saying:

In the next seat there was a bodhisattva named Immeasurable Effort, who said:

King AjÄtaÅ›atru again held the robe and placed it on him, but he immediately disappeared and only heard his voice saying:

MahÄkÄÅ›yapa said:

King AjÄtaÅ›atru then put the robe on him.

Give the robe to the one who appears.

As one sees one's own doubts, one sees all dharmas in the same way.

The king saw nothing more, so he took the robe and tried to put it on himself, but he also could not see his body. His mind, consciousness, and all thoughts were gone. This is called liberation from thoughts and liberation from doubt.
He then emerged from samÄdhi and saw the assembly of bodhisattvas, bhiká¹£us, officials, and all beings as before.
AjÄtaÅ›atru again said to MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«:

MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said again:
Do you see the assembly?
AjÄtaÅ›atru said:
I see.

Do you see the assembly?
AjÄtaÅ›atru said:
I see.

Manjushri asked again:
What do you see as doubtful?

Manjushri said:
Have you heard the Buddha say that those who commit grave offenses will enter the great hells?
The king said:

When the Buddha attained Buddhahood, were there any who ascended to the heavens or entered the hells?

No.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½

The Dharma body is neither in the heavens nor in the human realm, nor in the hells, animals, or hungry ghosts.
Those who commit offenses are also not apart from the Dharma body. The bodies of those who commit offenses all enter the Dharma body, and the roots of all offenses are the roots of all dharmas.
The past and future have no coming or going, and all dharmas also have no coming or going.
Knowing this, one neither enters the hells nor ascends to the heavens, nor does one attain nirvana.

The king then replied:

If one contemplates that there is no self, then there is no person, no one who commits offenses, and no one who experiences the consequences of offenses.

Has the king already been liberated from doubts?
He replied:

Have those doubts been exhausted?

They have been exhausted for a long time.

How does the assembly know that the king has neither offense nor liberation in the midst of this?
The king said:

AjÄtaÅ›atru said to Na-qi-tou Liang-ya:
Are all offenses purified by attaining this forbearance?
The king said:
Because all dharmas are pure and untainted.
This Dharma is also undefiled.
Why is it so?
Because the Way is free from defilement.
Those who enter the Way of Great Adversity do not leave birth and death, nor do they see nirvana.
Why is it so?
Because the Way has nothing that can be reached or approached.
When these words were spoken, King Ajatashatru immediately attained the forbearance of swift faith.
At that time, thirty-two people all gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment in front of Manjushri, and five hundred officials attained the path of stream-entry.

MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« then touched the ground with his big toe, and the palace walls and ground all became like beryl. After MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« had expounded the Dharma for the king, the palace ladies, and the officials, he sent them all off safely, then rose from his seat, left the palace gate, and went with the bodhisattvas and bhiká¹£us.
King AjÄtaÅ›atru and the palace attendants all saw him off.
Outside the city gate, he saw a man under a tree who was crying out, I have killed my mother!
This man was about to be executed. MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« transformed himself into a man who was walking with his parents.
His parents said:
Therefore, the right path can be followed by doing this.
The son said:
This is not the right path.
In this way, up to the second and third time, he argued with his parents, and then had the thought to kill his parents.
The one who had previously called out to kill his mother saw this person killing his parents, and then raised his voice by the side, and the transformed person who killed his parents then confessed:
What I have done is not in accordance with the Dharma, and I have resentfully killed my parents.
That person then thought:
I have only killed my mother.
This person has killed his parents, and his crime is very grave.
As for what the son has received, I am still insignificant.
The transformed person then said to the one person:
I should go to where the Buddha is.
The Buddha is the one who accepts those who have no refuge, and becomes a protector for those who have no protection.
As the Buddha has said, I will uphold the teachings and dare not violate them.
The person who was teaching them then went on the road, and one of them followed behind, saying:
The Dharma that this person has received, I also receive in the same way.
Although it is so, I still praise him.
They all cried as they walked.
They arrived at the Buddha's place, bowed before him, and stayed. They then said to themselves:
We have done an unwholesome act and falsely killed our parents.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
As the child says, it is sincere and without difference.
Why is it so?
Because you do not conceal the crime you have committed, and what you have said before the TathÄgata is true.
The Buddha then said:
Do not be afraid, do not be anxious, follow what I say.
The transformed person said:
As the Buddha teaches, may you have compassion and protect me.
The Buddha said:

Return and observe the Dharma of the mind yourself. Look at the mind that you have held in the past, will hold in the future, and are holding in the present. With what kind of mind did you kill your parents?
The Buddha then said again:
The past mind has already ceased and is exhausted, and it cannot be seen where it is or where it is located.
The future mind cannot be spoken of.
Why is it so?
Because it has not yet arisen, does not yet exist, and has no existence, it has no conceptualization and no recollection.

The present mind also has no fixed abode. When the mind arises, the intention ceases. It does not gather together, and it cannot be known where it goes or where it comes from. It cannot be known as blue, nor can it be known as red, white, yellow, or black.
The mind cannot be seen, it has no form, it cannot be grasped, and it has no companion, just like an illusion.
It cannot be seen within the body, nor can it be seen outside, nor can it be seen in between.
The Buddha said:
The mind cannot be seen due to desire, nor can it be seen due to anger.
If one lies down and sees the mind in dreams, whether it is acting or not acting, the mind also has nothing to give and nothing to obtain.
The mind is originally pure, and therefore it is also undefiled, and there is also no one who purifies it.
The Buddha said again:
The mind is neither here nor there, like an illusion that cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
Because it has no companion.

One who knows this does not form such thoughts, does not think of self or non-self, does not think of anything to be seen, does not think of anything to abide in, but all dharmas are tranquil yet have an agent.
One who has faith in this will no longer undergo evil destinies.
Why is it so?
Because it is undefiled.
The mind and its dharmas are also unborn and unattached.
The transformed person said:
Excellent, excellent!
Just as the TathÄgata attained Buddhahood through the Dharma body, I now understand as the Buddha has said.
With faith and no doubt, there is no doer and no one who receives punishment, no one who is born and no one who is extinguished.
As with all dharmas, I aspire to become a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The Buddha said:
As the son wishes.
At that time, the transformed person immediately became like a Å›ramaá¹‡a and said to the Buddha:
The crimes I have committed, killing my parents, have already been liberated and I have attained arhatship. I now wish to enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The Buddha said:
Do as you wish.
The transformed bhiká¹£u flew up twenty zhang into the air and then entered parinirvÄá¹‡a. Fire emerged from his body and burned his body.
The one who had killed his mother, having seen this person enter parinirvÄá¹‡a, fully heard what the TathÄgata had said, and then thought to himself:
The actions he has done are extremely heinous, yet now he has become a Å›ramaá¹‡a and attained liberation and parinirvÄá¹‡a.
My crime is still forgivable. Why don't I myself take refuge in the Buddha, and I too can reach this.
He then went forward, made obeisance to the Buddha, and confessed:
What I have done is unlawful, I have killed my own mother.
I now take refuge in you with my body.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
What you say is sincere and without falsehood, what you say is as you say.
Seeing the TathÄgata, you confess the crimes you have committed without concealing them.
Moreover, observe the Dharma of the mind, think of the past, the future, and the present mind, which mind kills its mother?
The past mind has already ceased, it is neither external nor internal, nor does it have a location.
The future mind cannot be spoken of, it has not yet arisen, it has not yet come into existence, it also has no thought and is the same as having a thought.
The present mind also has no place to abide. The mind that arises has no accumulation and is also not seen to go anywhere, nor can it be seen to come from anywhere.
The mind is not blue, red, yellow, white, or black. The mind has no form and cannot be seen, held, or heard.
Why is it so?
Because it has no sound.
It cannot be obtained and has no companion, just like an illusion.
It is also not seen externally, and internally it is also not obtained, and there is no place in between.
The mind is also not defiled, nor is it evil, nor does it have doubts.
The mind does not create, nor does it create anything, nor does it give, nor does it obtain.
Because the mind is originally pure, it is also not defiled, and it is also not pure.
The mind also does not exist in being or non-being.
The mind, if empty, cannot be obtained or grasped, and has no companion.

The wise do not think of these thoughts, do not create bondage, do not create purity, do not create anything to be seen, do not create a place, do not have a place to stop, and do not have anything to be attached to.
The liberated mind is therefore unobstructed and does not give rise to evil places.
Why is it so?
The mind's dharma is also not attached to anything, does not reach anywhere, and does not stop in the cycle of birth and death.
The one who killed his mother immediately had the fires of hell emerge from each pore on his body, the pain was indescribable, and he then confessed:
I now take refuge in the TathÄgata.
Please have compassion and protect me, allowing me to attain peace and security.
The Buddha then placed his golden hand on the man's head, and the fire immediately went out and his suffering was relieved.
He then knelt before the Buddha and wished to become a monk.
The Buddha said:
As you wish.
He then became a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The TathÄgata taught him the Dharma of the Four Noble Truths, and he immediately attained the Dharma eye, deeply penetrating its meaning and attaining arhatship. He then said to the Buddha:
Now I wish to enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
